newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Recent Russian T-bill price fall hits auction.
newsitem.headline: Recent Russian T-bill price fall hits auction.

text.p: The Finance Ministry had to pay above market levels at Wednesday's auctions of government paper as investors, worried by falling prices in secondary trading in the last few days, held back from the sale, dealers said.
Dealers said the auction results signalled a further small drop in prices when secondary trading resumes on Thursday.
"The Finance Ministry paid well above the market level at both auctions," said International Moscow Bank dealer Yevgeny Krayev.

"On the whole it was preconditioned by the lack of demand, including from non-residents. The volume of non-competitive bids at the T-bill auction was only two-thirds of all the bids and one-third at the bond auction."
The average yield on the 308-day bills sold on Wednesday was 27.26 percent, compared with an average market yield on Tuesday of 25.60 percent. There is usually no trading on auction days.
"I think prices have to fall a bit tomorrow. It is clear it will fall a bit tomorrow within 0.10-0.15 percentage points," said Alfa-Bank dealer Alexander Inzhiyevsky.
